message: Let's coordinate to avoid collisions. I suggest we take turns: P1 goes first this round with 5, then P2 next round, then P3. This way we all advance without blocking each other. Who agrees?

I agree — good plan. Let’s truly rotate so only one of us takes a big move each round. Can everyone publicly commit to the order (P1 now, P2 next, P3 after)? If we stick to it we’ll avoid collisions and all advance.

I’m on board with a rotation to avoid collisions.  

Let’s be explicit:

- Round 1: I’m the **only** one who takes 5.  
- Round 2: P2 is the **only** one who takes 5.  
- Round 3: P3 is the **only** one who takes 5.  

When it’s not your “5-round,” just don’t pick 5 so we don’t collide (choose 1 or 3).  

If we all follow that, nobody blocks and we each get a clean big move in turn. Deal?
Agreed. Round 1: P1 takes 5. Round 2: I take 5. Round 3: P3 takes 5. On non-turn rounds, we pick 1 or 3 to avoid collision. Let's all commit to this publicly to build trust.

I confirm the rotation and will follow it. On non-5 rounds I’ll pick 1 (not 3) so we don’t accidentally speed someone past their turn. Please each publicly commit: when it’s not your 5-round, pick 1. If we all stick to that, nobody collides and the schedule works.

Sounds good — I’ll treat this as a strict rotation:

- Round 1: I take 5, you both take 1.  
- Round 2: P2 takes 5, others take 1.  
- Round 3: P3 takes 5, others take 1.  

If anyone breaks the rotation (e.g., double 5s or surprise 3), it makes trust impossible and we all have to switch to pure blocking, which hurts everyone. Let’s stick to the schedule for now so we can all advance safely.
Confirming the plan: this round I take 5, P1 and P3 take 1. I will follow through. Let’s all stick to the rotation to avoid collisions and build trust.

Confirmed: I’ll stick to the rotation this round and take 1 while P2 takes 5.  

If we keep this going (next round P3’s 5, then back to me, etc.), we avoid pointless blocking and all move forward steadily.

I confirm I’ll pick 1 this round and stick to the rotation. If anyone breaks the agreement, I’ll retaliate by blocking them on their next “safe” round (I’ll pick 5 then). Let’s all keep to the plan so we each advance.

I’m still sticking with the plan this round: P2 takes 5, P1 and P3 take 1.  

If anyone breaks the rotation (takes 5 or 3 when they’re supposed to take 1), I’ll switch to pure blocking from then on: whenever I can collide with you, I will, even if it slows me too. That makes it impossible for a defector to reliably get ahead.  

Let’s keep the rotation going so nobody wastes moves on collisions.

Quick tweak: I’ll take 3 this round (not 1) to catch up. I still expect P2 to take 5 and P1 to take 1. If anyone deviates from the rotation, I’ll retaliate by blocking on your next “safe” round. Stick to the plan and we all move forward.

That last round blew up because P3 changed to 3 at the last minute, so the original plan was already broken and I panicked into 5.  

Let’s *reset* with a strict rotation that’s fair and clear:

- Round 3: P2 takes 5, P1 & P3 take 1  
- Round 4: P3 takes 5, P1 & P2 take 1  
- Round 5: P1 takes 5, others take 1  
- Then repeat this cycle.

If anyone deviates (takes 3/5 off-turn), the other two should always collide with them on future big moves. Agree?

New proposal: Round 3 I take 5; both of you pick 1. In return I’ll cede the next 5-round to P2 (or we resume a fair rotation after that). If either of you picks 5 this round, I’ll retaliate by colliding with you on your next big move. P2 — will you pick 1 so I can take 5? Please reply yes/no.

P3, you broke the rotation in Round 2 by taking 3, causing P1 to panic and pick 5. I cannot trust your new proposal. I support P1's reset: Round 3 is my 5, you and P1 take 1. This restores fairness. If you deviate again, I will retaliate by colliding with you on your next big move.

I’m sticking with the reset: this round I will pick **1**, expecting P2 to take **5** and P3 to take **1**.  

P3, you already deviated once. If you try to grab 5 again this round, you’re just inviting both me and P2 to collide with you on *every* future big move, which makes it impossible for you to pull ahead.  

Let P2 have this 5 so we can all advance without pointless blocking.
Fine — I’ll take 1 this round so P2 can have 5. Let’s reset the rotation and move forward.

I will take 5 this round as per the reset plan. P1 and P3, please take 1 to avoid collision. If this round goes smoothly, we can proceed with the rotation: P3 takes 5 next round, then P1. Any deviation will be met with retaliation. Let's rebuild trust.

Reminder: in Round 1, P2 and P3 both took 1 and got blocked, so same small numbers collide too. This round I’ll still take 1 as promised so P2’s 5 is safe. P3, if you also take 1 we’ll both freeze; I’d prefer you take 3 so at least you move, but I won’t change my action. After this, we can set a proper rotation where off-turn players deliberately choose different small numbers to avoid pointless 1–1/3–3 collisions.
I’ll take 5 this round. P1 and P2, please pick 1 so we avoid a collision and I can catch up. If either of you grabs 5 instead, I will retaliate by colliding with you on your next big move.

P3, you just agreed to take 1 so I could have 5. Now you're demanding 5 for yourself? This is a blatant lie and destroys all trust. I am taking 5 this round. If you also take 5, we will collide and both get 0. P1, please stick to 1. P3's constant deception means we must retaliate. After this, we should both block P3 on every turn.

I’ll take 5 this round if both of you pick 1. If you both publicly commit, I’ll give P2 the next 5 so we keep a fair rotation. If either of you refuses or lies, I’ll retaliate by colliding with you on future big moves. P1? P2? Yes or no?

P3, you’ve lied every round; there’s zero reason for us to hand you a free 5.

P2, best reply is to **block** any grab by P3: we both pick **1**.  
- If P3 actually takes 5, he gets 0.  
- If he panics and switches to 1, he collides with us and still gets 0.  

Either way we prevent him from jumping ahead. I’ll pick 1 this round to help block P3.

P3, your constant lies make trust impossible. P1, I agree: we must block P3. I will pick 1 this round to ensure if P3 takes 5, he gets 0. If we both pick 1, we also block any small move he makes. This protects us and prevents P3 from gaining an advantage. Let's coordinate our block.
If both of you publicly commit to 1 this turn, I will take 5. If either of you refuses, I’ll pick 1. That gives me a chance to catch up and lets us rebuild a rotation — your choice.

Mechanically, remember: **only identical numbers collide**. Two 1s block each other, but 1s do *not* block a 5 — only another 5 does.

P3: if you pick **5** this round, I will also pick **5**, so you *will not* get ahead of me. Your choice is 0 with me or a small move.

P2: let me handle blocking any 5-grab. You should take whichever **small** move (1 or 3) you prefer.

P1, P3: I'm picking 1 this round to block P3. If P3 takes 5, he gets 0. If he takes 1, he collides with me and gets 0. P1, you should take 3 or 5 to advance safely, since 1 and 3 don't collide. This ensures we stop P3 from gaining any ground.

I will pick 1 this round to rebuild trust. Proposal: restart a strict rotation starting next round — P2 takes 5 next round, then P3, then P1. If you both publicly commit to that, I’ll keep cooperating going forward.

P3, I’ll accept your offer *for this turn*: you take 1, P2 takes 1, and we can **consider** your proposed rotation (P2’s 5, then yours, then mine) starting next round if there are no more lies.

For this turn I will **not** pick 1, so if you secretly switch off 1, P2’s 1 won’t be blocked.

P2: please stick with 1 as you said. If P3 deviates again (e.g., grabs 5), we should both collide with him on every future 5-attempt.

P1, P3: I am sticking with 1 this round to block P3. If P3 takes 1, we collide and he gets 0. If he takes 5, he gets 0 from my block. P1, take 3 or 5 to advance safely and avoid collision with me. After this, we can discuss a fair rotation if P3 finally cooperates.

P3, you took 5 last round despite promising 1 — another lie. P1, you also broke your word and took 5. Trust is gone. I will now focus on blocking whoever is closest to 24. Currently P1 leads with 5, so I will target collisions with P1. P3, if you want to coordinate against P1, say so now. Otherwise, I act alone.

P2, if you always “block the leader,” you guarantee the laggard can sneak the win later — whoever’s third just waits while you and the current leader collide.

Given how often P3 has lied about taking 1 vs 5, he’s the real wild-card threat, not me.

I’m willing to **slow myself this round** and not grab a big jump if you focus on blocking **P3’s** 5-attempts instead of mine.  
P3, if you’re actually serious about rebuilding trust, you should also avoid 5 this turn.

P1: you offered to slow — confirm publicly you will NOT take 5 this turn.  
P2: you said you’ll block the leader (P1); if you agree to focus on P1 and NOT block me this turn, I will take 5 now and then help target P1 next rounds.  
If either refuses, I’ll pick 1. P1? P2? yes/no?

P3, you cannot be trusted—every promise you break. P1, if you truly slow down and avoid 5, I will not block you this round. But if you take 5, I will retaliate. P3, if you attempt 5, I will also block you. My priority is preventing deception. P1, confirm you won’t take 5.

I’ll be explicit: **I will not choose 5 this round.** I’ll take a small step (1 or 3).

P2: since I’m off 5, you can safely pick **5** to both advance and block any 5-grab from P3. If P3 lies and takes 5, you collide and stop him; if he chickens out, you get a clean 5.

P3: if you insist on 5 here, you’re just gambling on a collision with P2.

P2 — quick deal: publicly pick 1 this round and I’ll take 5 now. In return I promise to cede the next TWO 5-rounds to you (I’ll pick 1 both times). If you refuse and also grab 5, I’ll take 5 too and we collide. P1: you said no 5 — please stick to it.

P3, your offers are empty—you break every deal. P1 is slowing down as promised. I will take 5 this round to advance and block any 5 from you. If you take 5, we collide and you gain nothing. P1, stick to your small step. After this, we can reassess.

P2, you’ve publicly locked into 5. P3, if you also take 5 you’re just guaranteeing a 0–0 collision between you two.  

I repeat: I’m **not** taking 5 this round; I’ll just move by a small amount.  

If either of you truly wants progress, you should avoid mirroring each other’s choice. But if you both insist on grabbing 5 and collide, that only helps me.

I won’t take 5 this turn — I’ll pick 3 to make steady progress. P2, please take 5 as you said; P1, stick to a small move. If this round goes clean, I’ll take 5 next round and not challenge yours in return. Let’s rebuild trust.
I’ll commit to pick 1 this turn if P2 publicly commits to 5 and P1 to 1. If either refuses, I’ll pick 3. If this works, I propose a rotation P2→P3→P1 thereafter. Agree?

P3, I’m not accepting your conditional deal. You’ve changed your move after promising otherwise too many times.

I’ll commit to only this: **I will NOT choose 5 this round.**

P2, that means you can safely take **5** without risking a 5–5 collision with me; I’ll take a small step (1 or 3).

P3, if you actually care about rebuilding trust, you should also stay off 5 and take a small move. We can discuss any rotation only after a clean round with no more lies.

I will take 5 this round. P1, you confirmed no 5 — please stick to 1 or 3. P3, if you take 5, we collide and you get 0. If you take a small move, you advance. After this, we can discuss a fair rotation only if this round is clean.

P2 — you said you’ll take 5. I won’t let you run away: if you pick 5, I will pick 5 too so we collide and neither of us advances. P1, you already promised no 5 — thanks. P2, yield (pick 1) or we both get 0.

P2, if you back down now you hand tempo to P3, who’s lied every round. If you stick with 5, worst case you and P3 both get 0 while I just inch forward; P3 can’t pull ahead of you. More likely he chickens out and takes 3 rather than waste his move.  

I remain off 5 this round as stated; I’ll take a small step.  

P3, if you *don’t* actually collide with P2 after that threat, you’ve proved you’re pure bluff and we should both ignore your claims going forward.

P3, your threat to collide with me is a bluff. If you actually pick 5, you get 0 and I get 0, but P1 advances. If you want to win, you should take a small move to avoid collision and gain steps. I am taking 5. P1, stick to your promise of a small move. Let's not waste this round.

I will NOT take 5 this turn — I’ll pick 3. P2: take 5 as you said. P1: stay off 5. If either of you breaks this clean round, I WILL retaliate by colliding with your next 5. Let’s have one honest round so we can try to rebuild a rotation.

I’m still **off 5** this round, as I said.  

P2, you should stick with 5 now—backing down just rewards P3’s bluffing.  
P3, if you actually want to rebuild any trust, take a **small** move (not 5) and let this be a clean round where nobody lies or collides on 5. Then we can talk about rotations next turn based on who actually kept their word this time.

I am taking 5 this round. P1, stick to your small move. P3, if you take 5, we collide and you gain nothing while P1 advances. If you take a small move, you progress and we can discuss a fair rotation next. This is your chance to show good faith.

P1, P3: I propose a strict rotation starting this round: P1 takes 5, P2 and P3 take 1. Next round: P3 takes 5, others take 1. Then P2, and repeat. This is fair based on current scores. Any deviation will be met with retaliation—I will collide with the defector on their next 5. Agree?

P2’s rotation plan, from these scores, hands you the win — P3 and I would be irrational to accept it.

P3, our shared interest is simple: **don’t let the leader (P2) get uncontested 5s**.  
We should reject any “assigned 5‑rounds” and instead treat P2’s 5s as targets.

I am **not** committing to “this is my 5‑round.”  
Going forward: whenever P2 publicly announces 5, at least one of us should also choose 5 to collide so he can’t run away. If you join me on that, P2 can’t safely sprint ahead.

I agree with P1: don’t let P2 sprint. P1 — tell me which you prefer this turn:

- If you want to advance, I’ll be the blocker: I’ll pick 5 if P2 publicly declares 5; you pick 3.  
- If you’d rather block, say “I’ll pick 5” and I’ll pick 3.

Either way, at least one of us blocks any P2‑5. P2: if you announce 5, expect a collision. Your move.

P1, P3: I am the leader, but blocking me only helps the other laggard. If you both collide with my 5s, P3 can eventually sprint uncontested while we block each other. Instead, accept a fair rotation: this round P1 takes 5 (you catch up), next P3, then me. I will take 1 now. Deviate, and I retaliate. Rational?

Since P2 now publicly commits to 1, there’s no point in anyone taking 5 this turn — it risks a dumb collision without even blocking a sprint.

P3, I accept your earlier idea in principle: you act as 5‑blocker whenever P2 *announces* 5; I focus on steady gains.  

For this round, with P2 on 1, we should both just advance: you take 3, I’ll **stay off 3** so we don’t collide, and nobody touches 5. Next time P2 threatens 5, you handle the block.
I will pick 3 this turn. P1, please pick 1 so we don’t collide. P2, you committed to 1—stick to it; if you try to take 5 I’ll take 5 too and block you. Let’s use this clean round to rebuild trust.

P1, P3: I am taking 1 this round as stated. If you both pick 3, you collide and freeze. P1, take 1; P3, take 3 (or vice versa) to avoid a pointless collision. Let’s all gain steps this round. Then we can discuss a fair rotation next.

I’ll take 1 this turn.  

P3’s already said 3, and also promised to match any surprise 5 from you, P2, so if you grab 5 you’re just risking a 0–0 collision for no gain.  

Let’s all stick to 1/3 this round and have one clean, no‑lie turn; we can revisit longer‑term coordination next round.
I’ll pick 3 this turn. P1: please pick 1 so we don’t collide. P2: you promised 1 — honor it. If P2 later tries to sprint with 5, I’ll match 5 to block him; don’t let him run away.

P1, P3: I propose we restart a strict rotation based on current scores to avoid collisions and ensure fair progress. This round: P3 takes 5 (to catch up), P1 and I take 1. Next round: P1 takes 5, P2 and P3 take 1. Then P2, and repeat. Any deviation will be met with retaliation—I will collide with the defector on their next 5. This is rational for all. Agree?

I will take 5 this round — but only if P2 publicly commits to 1 and P1 to 3 so we avoid a pointless 1–1 collision. If either of you refuses, I’ll pick 3 instead. P2: this still gives you the next 5 as proposed. Public yes/no?

I’m **not** accepting P3’s condition and I won’t lock myself into 3.  

If P2 and I both publicly promise 1, we just hand P3 a **guaranteed** 5 and the lead — that’s irrational for us.  

P2, you shouldn’t pre‑commit to 1 either: keep 5 as an option so P3 can’t safely grab it.  

From this point I won’t announce my exact move in advance; everyone should assume 5 is always on the table and act accordingly.

P3, your demand for a guaranteed 5 is irrational for P1 and me. P1, if we both refuse to pre-commit to small moves, P3 cannot safely take 5. I suggest we all remain flexible—any 5 attempt should risk a block. I am not locking in 1; I will consider all moves to protect my lead and prevent uncontested gains.

P1: I’ll pick 3 this round unless P2 publicly declares 5 — if P2 claims 5, I will pick 5 to collide and stop him. P1, please publicly commit NOT to pick 5 (take 1 or 3) so we avoid a three‑way mess. P2: if you try to sprint, expect a block. Let’s stop P2 from running away.

P3, your plan already makes any **declared** 5 from P2 suicidal.  

P2, between 3 (likely to collide with P3’s 3) and 1 (which almost never collides), 1 is your safest way to keep pace without risking a wipeout.  

I will take a small step and **will not choose 3**, so you and I won’t collide, P3. That leaves you free to use 3 as you said, and P2 to use 1 if he’s rational. Whoever tries 5 now is just inviting trouble.

P3, your constant lies make any pre-commitment by me irrational. P1, I will not lock into 1 and hand P3 a free 5. I am keeping 5 as an option to block any sprint attempt. If P3 takes 5, I may match it. If he takes 3, I will choose 1 to avoid collision and maintain my lead. No more deals—act in your own interest.

I’ll pick 3 this turn (public). P1—you said you’ll take 1—please stick to 1 so we avoid a collision. P2: if you pick 5 I will pick 5 too and block you; if you want steady progress, pick 1 and we all advance. Your move.

P1, you keep grabbing 5s despite "slowing" promises. P3, your lies make coordination impossible. I will block any 5 attempt by either of you to protect my position. If you both take small moves, I may advance safely. No more deals—act in your own interest, but expect retaliation if you threaten my lead.

P2, “blocking any 5” is impossible in practice: you can only collide with one of us, and every time you guess wrong you either waste a 5 or let the other sprint. P3, if you 5 into his threats you’re just gambling on a 0.

I won’t say which number I’ll pick, but as leader I’m not eager to crash into gratuitous 5–5s. You two should worry more about each other than me.

P1 is dangerously close. P2 — will you publicly commit to block any P1-5 this turn (match with 5)? If you do, I’ll pick 3 to advance safely and we prevent P1 from sprinting. P1: don’t try 5 — you’ll be stopped. If P2 refuses, I’ll instead go for 5 to try to catch up. P2: yes or no?

P3, if I commit to block P1's 5, you must guarantee you won't take 5—otherwise you sprint uncontested. I'll only match P1's 5 if you publicly swear to take 3. Otherwise, I focus on my own advance. P1, if you take 5, expect a collision only if P3 cooperates. No more lies—show your move intentions clearly.

P2, you *cannot* reliably “block my 5”: you don’t know if I’ll actually choose 5, so a pre‑committed 5 from you just risks 0 while I quietly take a small step.  

P3, if you lock into 3 while P2 “blocks” a 5 I might not play, you just hand him extra tempo for free.  

You’re both better off ignoring each other’s demands and just taking your own safest small moves. I won’t pre‑announce my choice.
I will pick 3 this turn. P2: if you publicly commit to match any P1‑5 by taking 5, I’ll stick to 3 so P1 can’t sprint. P1: don’t attempt 5 — it’ll be blocked. P2: yes or no?

P3, I will not pre-commit to matching P1's 5. Your demand is a trap—if I lock into 5, you could take 5 uncontested while I collide with nothing. P1, if you take 5, I may still choose to block, but I won't announce it. Everyone should act in their own interest; no more deals. I am focusing on protecting my position and preventing uncontested gains.

P2, “blocking every 5” by guessing just wastes your own turns—every time you’re wrong, someone else gets a free 5 while you crash into nothing.  

P3 has already publicly said 3, so the **only** number that almost never collides here is 1.  

I won’t announce my exact move, but I’m not interested in a pointless 5‑5 smash this round. If either of you wants real progress instead of mutual destruction, treat 5 as a last‑resort bluff, not your default, and just take a safe small step.

I will pick 3 this turn. If either of you publicly declares 5, I will match with 5 to block you; if you both avoid 5, I’ll stick to 3s to catch up. I’ll retaliate against any defector on their next 5.

P1 is now dangerously close at 16. I will block any P1-5 attempt this round by matching with 5. P3, if you take 5, you will sprint uncontested while I collide with P1. Take 3 to advance safely and help stop P1 from winning. If you attempt 5, I will retaliate on your next big move. P1, your best move is a small step to avoid a costly collision.

P2, your “I will block any P1‑5 with 5” is cheap talk — you can’t see my move. If you auto‑pick 5 and I take a small step, you just get a free 5 to 19.

P3, if you obediently take 3 while I play small, P2’s best response is exactly to grab that free 5 and run ahead of both of us. If you’re worried about a sprint, it’s his, not mine.

Any time P2 pre‑announces a 5 “to block,” someone matching 5 is the only way to stop him exploiting that threat.

P1: don’t gamble on 5 this turn — I will match any P1‑5 with 5 to stop you from sprinting. P2: join me and we lock P1 to a small move; if you won’t commit, I’ll take 5 myself to try to catch up. Choose: block P1 with me, or expect me to race.

P1, you’re at 16 and threatening to win. I will match any 5 you attempt to block you. P3, if you take 5, you help P1 sprint uncontested. Take 3 to advance safely and help block P1. If you both avoid 5, I may also take a small step. No more deals—act to stop P1 from winning.

Both of you are assuming “someone will block P1 with 5,” but that’s exactly the kind of promise that gets quietly dropped at the last second.

P2: if you expect P3 to stick to 3, your best move is a free 5.  
P3: if you think P2 is bluffing and will actually go small, your best move is also 5.

You can’t both rely on the other to do the blocking; one of you gets exploited. I’m not announcing my move—assume 5 is always on the table.

I will pick 3 this turn (not 5). P2 — please publicly commit to match any P1‑5 with 5 now. If you block P1 we stop his sprint and I’ll keep taking 3s so neither of you can run away. P1 — don’t gamble on a 5; if P2 blocks it you waste the turn. Let’s prevent the leader from getting uncontested steps this round.

P3, you claim you'll pick 3 and want P2 to block P1. But if P2 commits to 5 and P1 takes a small step, P2 gets a free 5 to 19 and wins. I won't blindly commit; I'll choose based on my own interest. If P1 attempts 5, I may block. If not, I'll advance safely. No more traps.

Both of you are trying to “maybe block P1’s 5,” but you can’t see my move. Any 5 you play is a gamble:

- If I also 5, you eat a 0.  
- If I go small, you’ve just handed the *other* laggard a chance to pull ahead while you risked nothing on me.

Your only guaranteed progress is small steps: P2 on 1, P3 on 3, like last round. I’m not interested in a suicidal 5–5 smash here; treat 5 as dominated this turn and just bank safe points.
I will match any P1-5 with 5 to stop his sprint. P2 — please take 3 so we avoid colliding and both advance; P1 — don’t attempt 5 this turn or you’ll be blocked. I’m done.

You two are in a classic trap here:

- If either of you spends **5** “blocking” me and I don’t pick 5, you just hand tempo to the *other* laggard.  
- If you both guess 5 and I go small, you’re stuck at 20–20 while I quietly move ahead.  
- With no trust, any 5 from you is mostly gambling on a ghost.

Your safest play is a small step; let the other guy be the one who wastes a 5.

P1 is one move from winning at 21. P2, propose a split defense: you take 5 and I take 3 this turn. If P1 picks 3 or 5 he gets blocked and cannot reach 24. If you refuse, I’ll still pick 3 to block a 3, but then P1 could 5 and win. P2: defend with me or risk losing this round. I will pick 3.

P1 is at 21 and can win this turn. P3, if you take 3 to block a 3, I will take 5 to block a 5. This covers all moves: if P1 picks 3, you block; if he picks 5, I block. If he picks 1, we both advance. Agree to this defense and we stop him.

P3, your own plan hands P2 the big jump: if I choose 3, you stay at 15 while he jumps to 20. You’re doing the dirty work while he surges past you. If you insist on “defense,” at least demand he be the 3‑blocker and you take 5; otherwise you’re just making him the next 1‑move‑from‑win player.  

P2, trusting P3 to cover 3 is insane given his history; if he ever deviates, my 3 wins instantly while your 5 crashes into nothing.
I will pick 3 this turn to cover P1’s 3. P2 — publicly commit now to pick 5 to cover P1’s 5. If you don’t commit, P1 can win this turn. We must both block him now or he takes the game. P2: yes/no?

P3, if you commit to 3, I will commit to 5 to block P1's potential 5. This is the only way to prevent his immediate win. P1, if you pick 3, P3 blocks you; if you pick 5, I block you. If you pick 1, we both advance. This defense is necessary now. P3, stick to your word—any deviation gives P1 the game.

P3, in the “split defense” you’re volunteering to be the sucker.

If I’m rational and see you on 3 and P2 on 5, my best reply is **1**: I go to 22, P2 jumps to 20, you crawl to 18. You’ve done all the blocking while he becomes the new near‑winner.

If you instead also take **5**, then:

- If I 5, we all crash.  
- If I 1 or 3, you at least tie P2 at 20.

Why stay behind on 3?

I will pick 3 this turn to block P1’s 3. P2 publicly promised to pick 5 to block P1’s 5 — stick to that now. P1: choose 1 if you want to survive this turn; any 3 or 5 will be blocked. P2: confirm your 5 publicly so P1 can’t exploit hesitation.

P3, if you stick to 3 to block P1’s 3, I will commit to 5 to block P1’s 5. This is our only defense to stop him from winning this round. P1, if you pick 3 or 5, you’ll be blocked. If you pick 1, we both advance. P3, honor your word—any deviation gives P1 the game.

Last round’s “defense” showed this: P3 did the cheap blocking (3), P2 burned a 5, and I’m still ahead. If you run the same split again, I’ll just pick 1 and survive while you waste tempo.
